text: this week's movies the Blue Room keep on

jason reitman latest film men women and
children is an examination of the lives
of suburban teenagers and their parents
in the era of the smartphone in the
internet in his review a Oh Scott writes
as is often the case with multi plotted
movies like this one some stories are
too neatly packaged as cautionary tales
but others manage at least to hint at
the confusion and stickiness of real
life my mom
she checks my facebook my emails my
texts she must have just deleted it
before I even saw it the director has
the wisdom to realize that the internet
cannot entirely be blamed for the
unhappiness he surveys but this
conclusion undermines the film's premise
dissolving the thematic glue that holds
the stories together how do you know I
just do this to keep you safe veering
between technology and shrugging
resignation men women and children
succumbs to the confusion it tries to
illuminate equivalent illusion this is a
message in flow ask additional Belden

an adulterous married couple find

Manohla Dargis writes this dark
delectable shivery tale sets its uneasy
dank mood with energetic economy the
quizzical nor give you food to swallow a

graceful through the story's violent
turns its mood changes in tone shifts
the film is exciting although it moves
too fast for you to linger
appreciatively over his filmmaking as
the movie unfolds with the same terrific
velocity as its source material
